awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant for Hurricane Island Field Research Station
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the successful planning and development of the Hurricane Island Field Research Station, by cultivating and collecting information, ideas, and advice from research and higher education leaders with extensive field station experience. Hurricane Island is a growing science and education organization, and the Hurricane Island Field Research Station will be uniquely positioned to conduct research and provide educational opportunities with meaningful impacts on communities near and far. As the only offshore research station in the ecologically significant Penobscot Bay, the station will offer: unique access to water and land environments for research and educational purposes; a base of operations offering room and board, laboratory, and classroom facilities; a core group of year-round staff and seasonal research staff; a 3.2-acre aquaculture farm for research and education purposes; a model for sustainable station campuses and systems; and unique broader impact collaborations resulting from the educational programs taking place on Hurricane. With a fundamental commitment to providing access and education for underrepresented groups and creating an inclusive community, the station expands access for broad audiences to participate in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. Identifying new areas for community-driven research, deepening partnerships for long-term monitoring efforts, and developing a data-sharing plan, will greatly expand Hurricane's impact to support public education and research regarding important ecological issues in Maine's coastal communities and beyond. 

The objective of the proposed planning study is to work with stakeholders to develop a long-range strategic plan for the newly constructed Hurricane Island Field Research Station on Hurricane Island in Penobscot Bay, Maine. Funds will be used to bring together stakeholders consisting of an external advisory committee, research faculty, K-16 educators and students, local community members, and key Hurricane Island staff members for two workshops. The goals are to: identify community-driven research questions; develop a 5-year marketing and recruitment plan to meet targets for use of the facility; and develop a plan for data acquisition, management, and sharing. The workshops will be geared toward Hurricane Island's strategic priorities, including greater engagement between scientists and a variety of groups historically underrepresented in the STEM fields. The Field Research Station will continue to expand Hurricane's undergraduate and graduate programming as a host site for field projects and courses and increase research and educational capacity for existing partnerships. The capacity building associated with the Field Research Station will amplify current work in addressing community-driven questions through applied research and enhance collaborations by connecting scientists and students. For more information about the Hurricane Island Field Research Station, visit www.hurricaneisland.net/science-research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hurricane Island Center for Science and Leadership (Hurricane Island) utilized Field Stations and Marine Labs funding to bring together a diverse group of stakeholders in shaping the research priorities for the newly developed Field Research Station (FRS). This collaborative effort aimed to build a foundation for community-driven research addressing critical environmental challenges in the Gulf of Maine. Through workshops, surveys, and community conversations, Hurricane Island identified research themes that reflect the needs and interests of regional scientists, educators, fishermen, and communities. 

The outcome of this project was a research vision aligned with Hurricane Island’s strategic priorities, with a focus on enhancing ecological and economic resilience in response to climate change and environmental pressures. We also created a comprehensive data management plan that ensures the accessibility, integrity, and useability of the data generated by the FRS, enabling both the scientific community and local stakeholders to benefit from the findings. To support the long-term success of the FRS,  a 5-year marketing and recruitment strategy was outlined, aimed at attracting researchers, educators, and students, fostering a collaborative research environment that bridges academic, community, and policy-making sectors. We have used the insights gained from stakeholder engagement to guide the pursuit of funding opportunities and the implementation of research projects that address the identified priorities, such as long-term marine monitoring, sustainable aquaculture, and the impact of climate change on local ecosystems.

The specific results of our efforts include:

Community-Developed Research Plan:

  1. Produced a community-developed research plan that outlines key research priorities and strategies for engaging local stakeholders in ongoing and future research projects.

Enhanced Stakeholder Relationships:

  1. Strengthened relationships with the Vinalhaven fishing community, regional scientists, and other local stakeholders, ensuring that the Field Research Station is positioned as a valuable resource for addressing local environmental challenges.

Data Management Implementation:

  1. Implemented a data management plan that ensures the integrity and accessibility of research data, facilitating collaboration and data sharing among researchers, policymakers, and community members.

Successful Grant Funding and Research Initiatives:

  1. Secured additional funding for research projects that address the priorities identified through the community input sessions, such as the long-term monitoring of marine and intertidal environments and sustainable aquaculture practices. 

This project’s focus on community-driven research and engagement has generated impacts beyond the fields of science and technology. By actively involving local communities in the research process, the project has fostered a sense of ownership and stewardship over the natural environment, empowering individuals to take an active role in addressing environmental challenges. The community input sessions developed through this project have raised awareness about critical issues such as climate change, invasive species, and sustainable fisheries, helping build a more informed and engaged public. Additionally, the project’s emphasis on collaboration between scientists, educators, fishermen, and community leaders has strengthened social cohesion and promoted a collective approach to problem-solving. These efforts contribute to long-term resilience of coastal communities, ensuring that they are better equipped to navigate the ecological and economic challenges posed by a rapidly changing environment.
